content: Like other master limited partnerships, or MLPs, Phillips 66 Partners has seen a big rise in financial returns and stock price this year thanks to a combination of beneficial industry trends and a favorable business model. The company owns and operates oil and refined petroleum product pipelines and terminals. Heavy demand for fuel in the U.S. has helped the company…

U.S. refiners may have a more difficult time growing their exports in the next several years as they compete with increasing refinery capacity from the Middle East and Asia, analysts say. Russia also could be a formidable opponent for U.S. refiners in Europe, though the Kremlin's political standoff with the West muddles the outlook. Exports are critical to U.S. refiners,…

Valero Energy's (VLO) second quarter beat estimates as refining throughput volumes increased on discounted crude on the Gulf Coast.The refiner's Q2 earnings rose 27% to $1.22 per share, in line with an earlier announcement. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting $1.21. Revenue rose 2.6% to $34.9 billion, beating estimates for $29.2 billion.Shares were flat at 49.97 on the stock market today.Valero's refining throughput volumes rose 115,000 barrels per day to 2.7 million barrels per day as discounted light crude from shale plays in North America continued to flow to the Gulf.Phillips 66's (PSX) Q2 EPS rose 0.7% to $1.51, falling short of views by 19 cents. Revenue climbed 7.2% to $46.3 billion, under estimates for $47.5 billion.Shares fell 1% to 81.64.The refiner was spun off from ConocoPhillips (COP) in 2012. Refining earnings rose 27.5% to $390 million on higher volumes but was partially offset by weaker refining margins.Chemical-segment revenue jumped 79% to $324 million and accounted for nearly a third of total earnings.During the quarter, Phillips 66 raised its dividend 28% to 50 cents per share.The Oil & Gas-Refining/Marketing group is ranked No. 23 out of the 197 industry groups that IBD tracks.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich.

Pioneer Natural Resources shares jumped Wednesday after the Texas-based oil company got the OK from Washington Tuesday to export oil. Refiners' shares sank on the news.Domestic drillers Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and Enterprise Products Partners (EPD) received approval from the Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security to export condensate, a type of ultralight oil, reported the Wall Street Journal. Shipments can begin as early as August and likely will be small.The ruling probably will encourage other oil producers to ask for export permission, and the Commerce Department is working on an industrywide approval, according to the report. But as of Tuesday, the department said "no change in policy on crude-oil exports" has been made. By midafternoon, Pioneer Natural shares had traded up 4% to 230.57 in the stock market today, Wednesday. Enterprise Products shares rose 1.1% to 76.97.Separately Tuesday, Enterprise announced plans to build a 1,200-mile pipeline to connect the Bakken play in North Dakota to the oil pricing hub of Cushing, Okla.The pipeline will have a daily capacity of 340,000 barrels of oil and should be operational by the end of 2016.The Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration & Production group is highly ranked at No. 3 out of the 197 industry groups that IBD tracks.Only refined petroleum products can be exported under current laws. The ban started in the 1970s as an attempt to protect Americans from price spikes caused by Middle Eastern countries and OPEC using oil as a political weapon. But with the new influx of oil from previously unreachable plays in the Dakotas and Texas, many analysts and lawmakers believe that the ban is outdated.Refiners are the biggest opponents to lifting the ban and have benefited from the discount of light crude in the U.S., sending refined products abroad at much higher prices.Valero Energy (VLO) shares fell 10.6% to 50.08. Phillips 66 (PSX) fell 5% to 80.60.The IBD Oil & Gas-Refining/Marketing group is ranked at No. 17.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich.
Phillips 66 (PSX) reported first-quarter earnings that topped estimates Wednesday, but tightening crude spreads weighed on results.

The refiner's first-quarter earnings, ex items, fell 33% to $1.47. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting $1.34 per share. Revenue dipped 2.8% to $41.1 billion, falling short of analyst estimates for $42.9 billion.
Shares fell 0.5% to 83.31 in the stock market today, after hitting a record high on Tuesday.
Refining earnings fell to $306 million from $418 million in Q4.
"Our refining results were impacted by planned downtime at several of our Gulf Coast and Central Corridor refineries and tightening crude spreads," CEO Greg Garland said in the earnings release.
Phillips 66 is expanding its operations so that it has the ability to export refined products to 550,000 barrels a day by 2016.

New pipelines have eased the oil backup in Cushing, Okla., sending more crude flowing to the Gulf of Mexico but causing spreads to tighten. With more expensive crude, Phillips 66 and other refiners are spending more to make refined products such as gasoline and chemicals.

Tesoro (TSO) is expected to report results Wednesday after the market closes. Analysts anticipate a 41% drop in earnings to 43 cents per share and a 6.7% rise in revenue to $8.7 billion. Tesoro Logistics (TLLP), its petroleum logistics assets MLP, also reports tonight.
On Thursday, CVR Energy (CVI) and its spinoff CVR Refining (CVRR) are slated to report earnings.
Industry giant Valero (VLO) on Tuesday reported better-than-expected earnings. Shares hit a 6-year high that day before reversing lower. Shares were little changed Wednesday.

Valero Energy (VLO) reported first-quarter results Tuesday that topped analyst estimate thanks to higher refining margins in the Gulf. The largest domestic independent refining company said Q1 earnings jumped 30.5% to $1.54 per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting $1.38. Revenue rose 0.6% to $33.66 billion, above views for $32.95 billion. Shares rose 0.7% to 58.40 in the…
Tesoro (TSO) and its petroleum logistics assets MLP Tesoro Logistics LP (TLLP) reported earnings above analysts estimates late Wednesday.
Tesoro said first-quarter EPS fell 2.7% to 71 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 43 cents per share. Revenue climbed 35% to $9.9 billion, topping estimates for $8.7 billion.
The refiner's operating income fell 11% to to $264 million on weaker margins.
Shares rose 1.2% to 56.97 in the stock market today in after-hours trading.
Weaker margins have been a theme for refiners as new pipelines have eased the oil backup in Cushing, Okla., sending more crude flowing to the Gulf of Mexico and making crude more expensive.

Earlier Wednesday Phillips 66 (PSX) Q1 EPS fell 33% to $1.47, but still topped views and its revenue dipped 2.8% to $41.1 billion, falling short of analyst estimates for $42.9 billion. The company cited tightening margins as a reason for the decline in earnings. Phillips 66 shares fell 0.6% Wednesday. Refining giant Valero (VLO) and U.K. oil major BP (BP) also cited narrowing refining margins earlier this week.

Tesoro Logistics reported a 60% jump in earnings to 64 cents per diluted common limited partner units, topping analysts' estimates for 46 cents. Revenue jumped nearly 150% to $125 million, also beating views.
The master limited partnership was started in 2011 and provides crude oil transportation services.

With more pipelines online this year, the oil backup in Cushing, Okla., has eased and more oil is flowing to the Gulf of Mexico. The news is good for refiners such as Valero that price their oil at the Gulf. But it's making prices more expensive for refiners such as CVR Refining and Phillips 66 in the Midwest.
Valero Energy (VLO) kicks off the week for refiners, slated to report first-quarter results Tuesday.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are expecting the refiner to post an 18% jump in earnings to $1.39 per share. Revenue is seen falling nearly 4% to $32.9 billion.
Phillips 66 (PSX), which was spun off of ConocoPhillips (COP) in 2012, is expected to report Q1 results Wednesday.
Analysts are expecting the refiner Phillips 66 to post a 39% drop in earnings to $1.34 per share. Revenue is expected to rise 4% to $42.9 billion.
Tesoro (TSO) is also expected to report results Wednesday. Analysts anticipate a 41% drop in earnings to 43 cents per share and a 6.7% rise in revenue to $8.7 billion.

Incidentally, on Saturday the North Dakota Department of Health approved plans to restore land damaged by a pipeline operated by Tesoro. The project is expected to start in early June and last two years.

CVR Energy (CVI), a petroleum products refiner and marketer and a fertilizer-maker, will report quarterly results Thursday. Analysts are expecting a 59% drop in earnings to 74 cents per share, with revenue falling 4.5% to $2.25 billion.

CVR Refining (CVRR), a limited partnership formed by CVR Energy last year, is also scheduled to announce results Thursday. Analysts expect the company to report earnings of 74 cents per share and revenue of $2.07 billion.
Earlier this month the Energy Information Administration said domestic refinery production will increase by 60,000 barrels per day compared to last summer.

China's largest refiner, Shanghai Petroleum & Chemical (SHI), also known as Sinopec, soared 18% despite Thursday's head winds.
What exactly drove the move wasn't clear. One possibility: news reports looking into the deal struck by the Beijing-based firm last month to buy liquefied petroleum gas from Phillips 66 (PSX).

Liquefied petroleum gas is propane or butane, or a combination of the two. Natural gas is primarily methane. Both are a gas at room temperature, but can be liquefied which greatly compresses volumes for transport.
Natural gas is liquefied through refrigeration. LPG is liquefied by being compressed into a liquid form.

The Phillips/Sinopec deal shows the world's largest LPG buyer shifting away from traditional Middle East sources to plentiful U.S. supplies. Bloomberg reports that Chinese refiners have locked-up long-term contracts for deliveries estimated to hit 100,000 barrels per day by 2015-16. Sinopec plans to use the gas as a raw material for chemical production. It is also widely used in cooking, heating, transportation fuel and aerosol propellants.
The timing points to a number of critical pieces of the LPG supply chain falling into place.
Phillips 66 announced in October plans to build a $1 billion LPG export terminal. It targets export capacity of 4.4 million barrels per month, roughly equivalent to four large carriers.

Enbridge Energy Partners (EEP) is constructing two other terminals totaling more than double the Phillips facility's throughput. LPG terminals face much lower regulatory hurdles than do LNG liquefaction facilities, and all three new LPG sites are set to come on line next year.

Among the world's largest fleets of LPG carriers are Belgium-based Exmar and Norway's Solvang ASA, Nippon Yusen in Tokyo and StealthGas in Athens, Greece. Many of the ships in those are classified as VLCCs — technically: very large crude carriers.
Navigator Holdings (NVGS) is the largest operator of handymax LPG carriers. These smaller ships can fit through the Panama Canal, shaving 8,000 miles off the trip from Houston to China.

That will change when the widened canal comes on line next. VLCCs will then be able to use the shortened route, almost halving what is now a 42-day excursion.China's largest refiner, Shanghai Petroleum & Chemical (SHI), also known as Sinopec, soared 18% despite Thursday's head winds.What exactly drove the move wasn't clear. A road trip to the beach or mountains is going to be slightly easier on the wallet this year as gas prices are expected to be lower than last year. During the busy vacation driving season of April through September, regular gasoline prices are expected to average $3.57 per gallon, 1 cent lower than last year and the lowest summer…
Stock futures tunneled into deep losses ahead of Thursday's open, as instability in China's markets sent a shudder through global investor confidence for a second time this week.
The stock market today again took significant cues from China, where markets opened in a sell-off after a sharp devaluation in the yuan spooked investors.

The CSI 300, which tracks blue chip stocks on the Shanghai and Shenzhen markets, dropped more than 7% in the first half-hour of trade, triggering automatic shutdown rules put in place on Monday. Chinese investors were already on edge ahead of next week's lifting of a six-month sales ban on large shareholders.
The Shanghai Composite ended with a 7% loss, leaving it 11.8% lower this week. The Shenzhen Composite tumbled 8.2% for a 15.2% loss since Friday's close.
The selling carried powerfully into other markets, sending the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo down 2.3% and pressuring major indexes in Europe to losses in the 3% range near midday.

In the U.S., bonds and the dollar slipped. Oil prices slumped 4%, putting West Texas Intermediate just above $32 a barrel and down 12% this week — undercutting lows from 2008 and touching its lowest mark since December 2003 . Natural gas rose 1%. Gold added a fraction, topping $1,080 an ounce. Copper fell 3%.

There was good news on the economic front. Layoffs announced by U.S. employers declined 27.6% year over year to 23,622 in December — the lowest total in 15 years, according to consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas' Job Cuts Report.

For the year, 2015 had the largest number of job cuts since 2011, but with layoffs tapering toward year's end. In the fourth quarter, layoffs totaled 205,072, down 49% from Q3 and 12% lower than Q4 layoffs in 2014.
Unemployment claims dropped to 277,000 in the week ended Jan. 2, down from 287,000 in the prior week, the Labor Department said. Economist consensus had expected a deeper dip to 272,000 claims.
China-based stocks were clearly taking early hits: NetEase (NTES) and Alibaba (BABA) dropped 5% each.
Dow stocks shifted unanimously lower, and nearly half the index was down more than 2%, with Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and JPMorgan (JPM) approaching 3% losses.
Only a handful of S&P 500 stocks posted gains, led by Newmont Mining (NEM) and beer brewer and IBD 50 stock Constellation Brands (STZ), up 2% each.
Expeditors International (EXPD) dropped 8% to notch the S&P 500's biggest loss.

Among leaders, Avago Technologies (AVGO) shed 6%. The Singapore-based chipmaker ended Wednesday down 8% and just below its 50-day moving average. Avago's premarket stance implies possible damage to its cup-with-handle base.
NetEase has held its ground after pulling back in Monday's sell-off to test its 50-day moving average. Thursday's premarket action points to a possible open below that line of support.
Meanwhile, Alibaba has been struggling against resistance below its 200-day moving average.

Other losses on the IBD 50 cut across a variety of stocks. Globus Medical (GMED) dropped 4%. BP (BP) bought the majority of capacity at a Kinder Morgan Energy Partners' (KMP) mini-refinery near Houston as part of an inexpensive plan get past the ban on exporting U.S. crude oil.

Under the deal, BP will buy at least 80% of the capacity of the $360 million refinery. The plant is expected to open in July and produce 100,000 barrels of refined oil per day. The refinery will process the oil only slightly so it falls outside the ban. The plant costs just a tenth of the price of a full-scale refinery, prompting other oil companies like Valero Energy (VLO) and Phillips 66 (PSX) to look into similar refineries.
BP shares were flat at 48.89 in the stock market today.

Energy companies have been trying to get Washington to remove the 41-year-old export ban in recent years. The law was set in place after the Arab oil embargo of 1973. But many in the industry believe the rule is outdated as the U.S. has excess oil from the large shale plays in Texas and the Dakotas. Technological advances in fracking and horizontal drilling have made previously unreachable oil relatively easy to extract.
As the turmoil in Ukraine increases, supporters of lifting the crude ban say oil and natural gas exports could loosen Russia's hold over Europe with its oil dominance.

But not everyone agrees the ban should be lifted. Daniel Weiss, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, told Bloomberg he supported the ban and exporting the slightly refined oil could cause U.S. gas prices at the pump to go up.BP (BP) bought the majority of capacity at a Kinder Morgan Energy Partners' (KMP) mini-refinery near Houston as part of an inexpensive plan get past the ban on exporting U.S. crude oil.Under the deal, BP will buy at least 80% of the capacity of the $360 million refinery. Today we're going to look at Phillips 66 Partners (PSXP), which operates oil and refined petroleum product pipelines and terminals. The firm was founded as a subsidiary of Phillips 66 (PSX), the oil and gas giant. As a Dec. 10 New America article article noted, most of its sales come from charging tariffs and fees for transporting and storing crude…
Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) continues its expansion into energy with the deal to buy Phillips 66 's (PSX) flow improver business.

In exchange for the business, Phillips 66 will receive roughly $1.4 billion in shares of its common stock currently held by William Buffett's conglomerate, under terms of the deal announced late Monday.
The exact number of shares will be determined at the deal close.
Phillips 66 shares jumped 3% to 76.97 in the stock market today. Berkshire's class B shares were up 0.4% to 118.56.
The acquisition of the flow improver business, which makes chemicals to boost pipeline flows, is the latest energy deal for Berkshire Hathaway.
Last month, it reduced its ConocoPhillips (COP) stake to 13.5 million shares from 24.2 million in June and disclosed a 40 million-share stake in Exxon Mobil (XOM).
In May, Berkshire doubled its stake in oilfield equipment maker National Oilwell Varco (NOV) to 7.5 million shares or $529.5 million.

Berkshire Hathaway's BNSF Railway has also benefitted from the U.S. energy boom by hauling crude from shale fields. But on Monday, a Burlington Northern train carrying crude oil crashed into another train in North Dakota causing an explosion that left 10 cars on fire. No injuries were reported.

The incident sparked renewed discussion about safety and the increase in traffic of oil-laden trails.Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) continues its expansion into energy with the deal to buy Phillips 66 's (PSX) flow improver business.In exchange for the business, Phillips 66 will receive roughly $1.4 billion in shares of its common stock currently held by William Buffett's conglomerate, under terms of the deal announced late Monday.The exact number of shares will be determined at the deal close.Phillips 66 shares jumped 3% to 76.97 in the stock market today. Berkshire's class B shares were up 0.4% to 118.56.The acquisition of the flow improver business, which makes chemicals to boost pipeline flows, is the latest energy deal for Berkshire Hathaway.Last month, it reduced its ConocoPhillips (COP) stake to 13.5 million shares from 24.2 million in June and disclosed a 40 million-share stake in Exxon Mobil (XOM).In May, Berkshire doubled its stake in oilfield equipment maker National Oilwell Varco (NOV) to 7.5 million shares or $529.5 million.Berkshire Hathaway's BNSF Railway has also benefitted from the U.S. energy boom by hauling crude from shale fields. But on Monday, a Burlington Northern train carrying crude oil crashed into another train in North Dakota causing an explosion that left 10 cars on fire. No injuries were reported.The incident sparked renewed discussion about safety and the increase in traffic of oil-laden trails.

If you want to make a splash on Wall Street with your initial public offering, it helps if your name is instantly recognizable to most investors.Phillips 66 Partners (PSXP) has that advantage.The company is a master limited partnership (MLP) that owns and operates oil and refined petroleum product pipelines and terminals.It was founded as a subsidiary of Phillips 66 (PSX), the Houston-based oil and gas giant that ranks as one of the world's biggest companies.Phillips 66 Partners' assets include a crude oil pipeline, terminal and storage system in Louisiana; a refined petroleum product pipeline, terminal and storage system in Texas; and another refined petroleum product pipeline, terminal and storage system in Illinois.The partnership gets just about all of its revenue by charging tariffs and fees for transporting, terminaling, and storing crude oil and refined products for Phillips 66.Auspicious StartPhillips 66 Partners had its initial public offering July 23. Its units priced at $23 a share, above the target range of $19 to $21. They opened at 28.98 on the first day of trading and closed at 29.70, up 29% from the IPO price.Shares then peaked at 35.94 on July 29, and they currently trade near 33.The early strength in Phillips 66 Partners' share price — and the reason for much of the optimism around the company's growth prospects — has a lot to do with its relationship with Phillips 66.In a report initiating coverage on Phillips 66 Partners, Citigroup analyst John Tysseland said the company is "set to benefit from a large portfolio of drop-down eligible assets from Phillips 66."He estimates that around $5.4 billion worth of crude oil, refined product and natural gas pipelines, terminals and other midstream assets that are still being operated by Phillips 66 "will likely be dropped down to the partnership" over the next three to five years."With the potential to add about $660 million in additional EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization), these drop-downs serve as the primary driver of double-digit distribution growth to PSXP over the next several years," Tysseland noted.BofA Merrill Lynch analyst Gabe Moreen has a similarly upbeat assessment, saying that Phillips 66 Partners offers unit holders "the ability to invest in a pure-play drop-down story with the potential for substantial cash distribution growth — driven by PSX's stable of logistics assets — as long as PSX continues to drop down assets at a reasonable pace and valuation."In most circumstances, it's risky to depend on one client for your business because of the possibility that the relationship goes sour somewhere down the line."If PSX becomes financially strained, does not support PSXP's growth, proposes changes to contractual terms, or defaults on contractual terms, PSXP would be materially impacted," JPMorgan analyst Jeremy Tonet noted in a report.MLPs A Rising TrendHowever, it's unlikely Phillips 66 would do anything to undermine the partnership. Phillips 66 is one of a growing number of oil and gas firms that have formed MLPs to operate their midstream business units. It has a vested interest in seeing the partnership succeed."PSXP is integral to its parent's business," noted John Edwards, analyst at Credit Suisse.He cites a couple of reasons. For one thing, Phillips 66 Partners' assets support the refining and marketing operations of PSX's refineries. For another, Phillips 66 Partners is a primary growth/financing vehicle for PSX's expanding transportation and midstream business.On a third-quarter conference call with analysts, Phillips 66 Partners Chief Executive Greg Garland said the parent company has plans to rapidly grow its midstream businesses and plans to use the partnership to achieve that growth."Given its large portfolio of midstream assets and strategy for growth, we anticipate near-term opportunities to acquire additional assets," Garland said. "This will allow for significant Phillips 66 Partners growth in the near-term and provide the platform on attractive growth profile longer term."Phillips 66 Partners charges fixed fees for the use of its pipelines, terminals, barge docks and storage facilities. All of the company's assets operate under long-term, fee-based transportation and terminaling agreements with its parent company."These agreements include specified minimum volume commitments and rate escalators, which provide the partnership with long-term, stable cash flows that have little to no direct sensitivity to commodity price fluctuations," Citigroup's Tysseland noted.Phillips 66 Partners reported its first quarter as a publicly traded company on Oct. 30.It posted transportation and terminaling revenue of $29.6 million, up from $21.3 million the prior year and above the $27.6 million expected by JPMorgan.Adjusted EBITDA came in at $19.2 million, up from $11.9 million a year earlier and above consensus estimates.Phillips 66 Partners is part of IBD's Oil & Gas-Transportation/Pipeline group. Master limited partnership peers in the group include Kinder Morgan Energy (KMP), Plains All American Pipeline (PAA) and Sunoco Logistics Partners (SXL).

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) chief Warren Buffett lavished more praise on Apple (AAPL) Monday, sending the iPhone maker's stock to a fresh all-time high.XDays after Berkshire Hathaway's annual shareholder meeting, Buffett told CNBC he would "love to own 100%" of Apple stock. His company currently has a 5% stake in Apple worth around $11 billion.Buffett's business partner and fellow billionaire investor Charlie Munger chimed in with a similar view."I think we've been a little too restrained," Munger told CNBC from Omaha, Neb. "I wish we owned more of it."Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWhile capital and regulatory hurdles make owning 100% of Apple impossible even for one of America's most revered investors, Buffett's words set Apple shares rallying again.Shares pared gains sharply but closed up 0.7% at a fresh high of 185.16 on the stock market today, after surging 3.9% to 184.25 on Friday, easily clearing a 179.04 buy point in a double-bottom base. A strong RS line and heavy buying volume backed Apple's breakout.Apple shares vaulted 13% last week thanks to an impressive earnings beat, a massive buyback plan and news that Berkshire Hathaway added 75 million shares to its stake in the technology giant in Q1.Apple has jumped 10% year to date vs. a 0.3% gain for the S&P 500.Other outperforming stocks in Buffett's stock investment portfolio year to date include Mastercard (MA) (25%), Sirius XM (SIRI) (25%) and Phillips 66 (PSX) (16%).YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Apple, Nvidia, Alibaba And This Regional Bank Share This Same Bullish BaseApple Leads Five Hot Stocks Now In Buy RangeNvidia Stock Breaks Out Ahead Of Earnings ReportBest Growth Stocks To Buy And Watch: See Updates To IBD Stock ListsLooking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Nine IPOs are slated for the week of July 22, including five biotech/biopharmaceutical companies.

Several recent biotech IPOs have performed well. Among them are OncoMed (OMED), which develops therapeutics targeting cancer stem cells. OncoMed popped 60% on its first day of trading Thursday. Among the largest IPOs next week is Phillips 66 Partners, which plans to raise $300 million. Other upcoming IPOs in the energy related field include Jones Energy and Marlin Midstream Partners.
Here are some IPOs slated for the week of July 22:
Phillips 66 PartnersTicker: PSXPLead underwriters: JPMorgan, Morgan StanleyIBD Industry Group: Oil & Gas, Transport/Pipeline (No. 85)

The company is a limited partnership formed by Phillips 66 (PSX) that owns pipelines and logistics assets. Phillips 66 Partners generates revenue primarily by charging tariffs and fees for transporting and storing crude oil and refined petroleum through its pipelines and terminals. Phillips 66 has said it intends to grow its transportation and midstream business and will use the partnership as a primary vehicle to achieve that growth.

Formed early this year, Phillips 66 Partners reported revenue of $21 million for the first quarter, up 15% from the year-earlier quarter, with net income of $10.7 million, up 32%. One risk factor is that Phillips 66 accounts for substantially all its revenue. Top performers in this industry group, based on a Relative Strength Rating, include Cheniere Energy (LNG) and Summit Midstream Partners (SMLP).
Agios PharmaceuticalsTicker: AGIOLead underwriters: JPMorgan, Goldman SachsIBD Industry Group: Medical- Biomed/ Biotech (No. 4)

Agios is a pre-clinical stage developer of molecule treatments for cancer and "inborn errors of metabolism." It plans to raise $75 million. Agios has a partnership with Celgene (CELG), which has agreed to purchase 12.75 million common shares of Agios in a separate private placement. Agios entered into a collaboration agreement with Celgene in April 2010. Agios aims to build a multi-product company and aggressively pursue development of novel medicines.

Founded in 2007, Agios reported first-quarter revenue of $6.2 million, the same as in the year-earlier period, and reported a net loss of $7.2 million. As of the end of the first quarter, it had an accumulated deficit of $81 million.
WCI CommunitiesTicker: WCICLead Underwriters: Citigroup, Credit Suisse, JPMorganIBD Industry Group: Building- Residential/Commercial (187)

WCI Communities is a developer of luxury residential communities and homes in Florida. It plans to raise $185 million. WCI is organized into three operating segments. The homebuilding unit, which accounts for 61% of revenue, built 352 homes in 2012, up from 128 in 2011. WCI also has a real estate services unit and a unit that focuses on amenities.

It was founded in 1946 and reported revenue of $241 million in 2012, up 67% from 2011. It said it swung to net income of $50 million from a loss of $46.3 million in 2011. HollyFrontier's (HFC) refining gross margins rose, but its first-quarter earnings missed analyst estimates as planned maintenance caused a dip in overall production levels for the quarter, sending shares falling in afternoon trading Tuesday.
The refiner said Q1 EPS climbed 41% to $1.63 but fell short of the $1.76 analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Revenue fell 5% to $4.7 billion, beating estimates of $4.6 billion.
Shares fell less than 1% in the stock market today. Phillips 66 (PSX) shares rose 1.5%. Valero (VLO) shares rose more than 2%.

HollyFrontier's refinery gross margins rose 34% to $23.32 per produced barrel vs. $17.46 in the first quarter of 2012. But operating expenses were $6.68 per barrel during Q1 compared with $241.6 million, or $5.51 per barrel, for the first quarter of last year.

The Oil & Gas-Refining/Marketing group is ranked No. 32 out of the 197 industry groups Investor's Business Daily tracks. While still highly ranked, the group has been falling in recent weeks. It was No. 9 eight weeks ago.
Cheap domestic crude has been boosting refiners' margins, but analysts are concerned that margins will narrow as the differences between domestic and foreign oil and natgas prices narrow.
Refiners could also take a hit if government regulations on fuel blends are increased. Ethanol credits still remain expensive and could weigh on future results.

Tech stocks were set for what could be a breakout bonanza Friday, spearheaded by Amazon.com (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Intel (INTC).  Overall, futures traded in mixed territory after first-quarter GDP data was better-than-expected, while quarterly reports from blue chip energy stocks delivered some disappointments.Nasdaq 100 futures strengthened to 0.5% above fair value, although futures had backed well away from gains posted in extended trade after Thursday's close. Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.2%. S&P 500 futures traded a fraction below fair value.Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) exerted downward force on both the Dow industrials and the S&P 500, slipping 2% after reporting first-quarter results.A big, 1.6% rebound for the Nasdaq on Thursday narrowed the index's loss for the week to 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrials index hauls a 0.6% loss into Friday's session, while the S&P 500 holds a slim 0.1% loss for the week. All three indexes are about 1 % below their 50-day moving averages.Get Free Access To IBD Digital Through April 29

Get premium stock lists, pass or fail stock ratings and more. Start HereThe Nasdaq 100 outpaced Thursday's action by a wide margin, surging 2.1% as Facebook (FB), Amazon, Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) all scored big gains. That left the index down 0.3% for the week through Thursday, after diving as much as 3.3% to a mid-session low on Wednesday.The message — it's a volatile market — is reflected in IBD's current Market Pulse market status indicator.Preliminary first-quarter GDP growth estimates from the Commerce Department were positive, with growth of 2.3% coming in below the fourth-quarter's 2.9% advance, but outpacing economist projections for a slowdown to 2% growth. The closely-watched price inflation number was also better-than-expected, with the GDP Price Index up 2%, below Q4's 2.3% increase and countering expectations for an uptick to 2.4% growth.Consumer spending met expectations for a 1.1% increase, although well below the prior quarters 4% surge.Leading tech names Expedia (EXPE), Amazon, and Intel reported quarterly results late Thursday.Expedia spiked 10.7% after reporting a narrower-than-expected first-quarter loss late Thursday, and a 15% rise in bookings, to $27.2 billion.Amazon hurtled ahead 7%. The e-commerce giant's first-quarter revenue topped analyst expectations, whereas earnings cleared targets by nearly 77%. The company also announced plans to raise the price of its Prime membership to $119, from $99. Chief Executive Jeff Bezos reported last week that Prime members numbered more than 100 million, worldwide. Amazon's premarket advance set the IBD Leaderboard stock for a starting bell breakout above a 1617.64 buy point in a six-week cup base. There is also an earlier, alternate entry at 1568.62.  The base is a very late-stage pattern. Premarket moves often do not carry over into regular trade.Intel stormed ahead 5.3%, seizing an easy early lead among Dow Jones stocks. A strong first-quarter profit and sales beat, and raised full-year guidance helped dissuade concerns lingering over security weaknesses discovered in its chips early in the year. Warren Buffett loaded up on Apple (AAPL) in 2017 — making it the second biggest stock holding in the Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) portfolio after Wells Fargo (WFC).As of 2017's end, Berkshire Hathaway's Apple stake totaled $28.21 billion in market value, up from $7.09 billion in 2016. Buffett started picking up Apple shares in 2016 and continued to bet big on the Mac, iPad and iPhone maker over the course of 2017. Apple jumped to second place on Berkshire Hathaway's list of 15 biggest stocks in 2017, up from No. 5 in 2016.There are no other technology stocks in Buffett's top stock holdings by value."If you look at our holdings, you would assume that we like them in the order in which they rank by dollar value of holdings, but if you look at them in terms of recent purchases over the last year we've bought more Apple than anything else," he told CNBC in an interview Monday, while heaping praise on Apple's "extraordinary consumer franchise."Here is the full list of Buffett's top 10 stocks by market value as of 2017 end:Apple accounted for a 16.5% stake of Berkshire's total stock investment portfolio at the end of 2017 vs. 5.8% at the end of 2016, as the portfolio surged in value over that period to $170.54 billion.Shares of Apple rose 2% to 178.97 on the stock market today. They are up 6.9% year to date and just below the record 180.10 set on Jan. 19. Berkshire Hathaway gained 3.9%, retaking its 50-day average, as Buffett described share buybacks as an option, American Express advanced 2.9%, Wells Fargo gained 1.35%, and Bank of America rose 1.2%. Cola Cola fell 1 cent to 44.03.Sign Up For Free IBD Newsletters: Market Prep | Tech ReportBerkshire's stock portfolio posted a 20.9% compounded annual gain between 1965 and 2017 vs. a 9.9% gain for the S&P 500 with dividends included.Buffett said Monday that he has "mostly" sold out of General Electric (GE). The troubled industrial giant is looking to make key divestitures even as Berkshire seeks to put its $116 billion cash pile to use with a big acquisition or two.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:These 3 Top-Rated Stocks Report Earnings This WeekHow To Make Money In Stocks Using The CAN SLIM Investing SystemThe Big Picture: Here Are Two Reasons To WorryNot Every Market Follow-Through Works: 2 Red Flags To Watch For

Warren Buffett lords over an empire that sells everything from candy to car insurance. And on Saturday, the Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) chief releases his hotly awaited annual letter to shareholders.X Investors in Berkshire Hathaway will look to learn what the Nebraska-based conglomerate will do with a rapidly swelling pile of cash that crossed $100 billion last September. They hope, too, for the 87-year-old chief to drop more clues on a succession plan.Buffett's letter to shareholders, combining insights from the legendary investor with humorous reflections, has appeared with clockwork regularity every year since 1977. They're archived on the Berkshire Hathaway website.Some Berkshire watchers are hoping the company will put its cash to use by expanding its portfolio of companies. Berkshire hasn't made a major purchase since its $37 billion acquisition of Precision Castparts, a maker of parts for jet engines and gas turbines, in 2015.CFRA analyst Cathy Seifert says Berkshire's acquisition strategy is less likely to focus on heavily regulated industries (like those in the financial services sector) when it can leverage upside to these industries via stock investments. Similarly, its technology exposure has been a result of investments, not acquisitions, she added."Against that backdrop, our sense is future acquisitions will likely be in the energy, materials and industrials areas, and possibly health care and consumer staples," she wrote in a note Thursday, without naming specific companies.It's a different story on Buffett's stock buys. Buffett started purchasing Apple (AAPL) in 2016 and has steadily raised his stake in the iPhone maker's stock, which has jumped 25% in the past year alone. Apple is now Berkshire's largest stock holding, accounting for roughly 15% of his $191.2 billion portfolio at the end of 2017.Seifert is also watching for these items in the chairman's letter:Class B shares of Berkshire Hathaway rose 1% to close at 202.76 on the stock market today.Sign Up For Free IBD Newsletters: Market Prep | Tech ReportAs Buffett struggles to find companies to buy, nearly all his cash hoard is held in U.S. Treasury bills. The cash pile increased by $3.3 billion this month after Phillips 66 (PSX) bought back 35 million shares from Berkshire Hathaway.Buffett may also write about using that money to pay a dividend — but the odds are slim. He's famously averse to such use of his money, but many Berkshire watchers say that a special cash dividend, a one-time affair at management's discretion, makes sense.On stock buybacks, Buffett has said he's open to such a move if the price falls below 120% of book value. As of Thursday, class B shares of Berkshire stock traded at about 160% of book value. But the giant cash stockpile may incline Berkshire's board and management to be less strict about that 120% buyback threshold, some say.Buffett's letter to shareholders also coincides with Berkshire's Q4 and full-year results.CFRA sees operating EPS of $6.32 in 2017 and expects underwriting results at Berkshire's core insurance and reinsurance units to remain under pressure in Q4, as damages from numerous disasters continued to pile up. But operating revenue growth in 2018 should quicken to 7%-9% from 6%-7% in 2017.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Why This 99 Composite Rating Stock Just PlungedHow To Make Money In Stocks Using The CAN SLIM Investing SystemThe Big Picture: Here Are Two Reasons To WorryNot Every Market Follow-Through Works: 2 Red Flags To Watch For

The S&P 500 index is essentially unchanged over the past four weeks, which is offering a chance for quality stocks to form new consolidations. Charles Schwab (SCHW), E-Trade Financial (ETFC), Phillips 66 (PSX), Vantiv (VNTV) and Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) are all in flat bases.XCharles Schwab, fellow online brokerage E-Trade Financial and refinery operator Phillips 66 are all members of the S&P 500 index. The S&P 500 index closed Friday at 2578.85, closing the fourth straight week of gains or losses of less than 0.3%. The S&P 500 rose modestly Monday afternoon.Charles Schwab, E-Trade Financial and Ollie's Bargain Outlet all have Composite Ratings above 95. Vantiv has a strong 91 while Phillips 66 is an OK 76. All-time winners often have Composite Ratings of at least 95 near the start of their big runs.IBD'S TAKE: Flat bases require a minimum of five weeks and typically the stock's decline is no more than 15% from the high to low of the consolidation. That suggests that the stock wants to move higher.Charles Schwab has been consolidating since Oct. 6, with a potential buy point of 46.31. Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) on Tuesday announced that it will take a minority stake in Pilot Flying J, a large truck-stop and travel-center chain, that will eventually grow to 80%, deploying some of the holding company's massive cash stockpile.XBerkshire in August reported that it had accumulated roughly $100 billion in cash, raising questions about how the company would use it. But the company's recent acquisition attempts have been stymied.Berkshire was outbid by Sempra Energy (SRE) for Oncor Electric Delivery, a large electric utility in Texas. And earlier in the year, Buffett-backed Kraft Heinz (KHC) dropped its plans to buy Unilever.Under the terms of Tuesday's deal, Berkshire will take a 38.6% in Pilot Flying J. The Haslam family will continue to hold a 50.1% ownership in the company until 2023. FJ Management will keep an 11.3% stake until that time.In 2023, Berkshire will snap up an extra 41.4% stake in Flying Pilot J, giving him 80% total. The Haslam family will keep 20% ownership. Other details of the deal were not disclosed."Jimmy Haslam and his team have created an industry leader and a key enabler of the nation's economy," Buffett said in a statement. Haslam is also the owner of the Cleveland Browns NFL team."The company has a smart growth strategy in place and we look forward to a partnership that supports the trucking industry for years to come," Buffett continued.Berkshire's class-B shares dipped 0.2% to 185.41 on the stock market today. TravelCenters of America (TA), which also operates roadside stops for truckers and motorists, jumped 8.4% to 4.50.IBD'S TAKE: Berkshire, a hot growth stock on the IBD 50 list, has racked strong profits and is showing favorable technical traits. Will recent hurricanes damage its performance?Flying Pilot J, which has more than 750 locations in the U.S. and Canada and serves truckers and interstate travelers, would add to Buffett's transportation-related holdings, which include names like American Airlines (AAL) and General Motors (GM). Buffett also owns a large chunk of oil refining giant Philipps 66 (PSX).RELATED:Warren Buffett: Hurricane Harvey Was Worse Than Irma For Car Insurer GeicoThis Berkshire Hathaway Executive May Replace Warren BuffettInsurance Stocks Tumble As Hurricane Harvey Impact MountsBerkshire Hathaway Outbid By Sempra For Oncor Electric Delivery

Gasoline prices across the U.S. are expected to climb even higher as the remnants of Hurricane Harvey continue to pound Houston and keep much of the Gulf Coast's refining capacity offline.XThe U.S. national average gasoline price was $2.31 per gallon Monday, up five cents from a week ago and up a penny from Sunday, according to GasBuddy.Prices are expected to go higher, from 7 to 15 cents the next two weeks with another increase if refineries are closed longer than two weeks, Patrick DeHaan, a senior petroleum analyst at GasBuddy, told MarketWatch.The price spike comes after 10 refineries, including Exxon Mobil's (XOM) Baytown, Royal Dutch Shell's (RDSA) Deer Park and Valero's (VLO) Corpus Christi refineries, responsible for an estimated 2.2 million barrels of daily capacity were closed ahead of the hurricane, according to S&P Platts.Gasoline futures for September delivery was up 2.7% to $1.712 a gallon, after spiking 5% earlier. Meanwhile, U.S. crude futures fell 2.7% to $46.57 per barrel, as refinery shutdowns lift stockpiles of unprocessed oil.Shares of Exxon, which has production and refining operations, fell 0.3% on the stock market today, while Shell, also an integrated oil major, dipped 0.4%. Refiner Valero rose 1.1%, and HollyFrontier (HFC) jumped 6.5% to 31.47, breaking out of a 31.37 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Phillips 66 (PSX) edged up 0.25% to 83.63, closing just below a 83.97 entry from a saucer with handle after rising to retake that intraday.IBD'S TAKE:  With thousands of publicly-traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? IBD's Leaderboard is showing a 60% increase over the S&P 500 so far this year.Pipelines were also shut in anticipation of the storm. Magellan Midstream (MMP) stopped operations on two pipelines that carry 675,000 bpd from the Permian Basin in Texas to refineries on the gulf coast, according to S&P Platts.  Kinder Morgan (KMI) shut down some of its 300,000 bpd pipeline.And nearly 22% of total offshore production was shuttered ahead of the hurricane, but Anadarko Petroleum (APC) said Sunday that it's resumed production on three platforms in the central Gulf of Mexico.RELATED: Energy Stocks And Industry NewsThis Chart Shows How Close U.S. Oil Production Is To A New Record High

Stocks opened sharply lower Tuesday as a North Korean missile firing sent global stocks lower and, in the U.S., the shutdown of Houston continued as Tropical Storm Harvey crept north into Louisiana.X The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 skidded 0.5% lower at the starting bell. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled 0.7%.Japan and South Korea went on high alert Tuesday, after a ballistic missile launched by North Korea flew over the north Japanese island of Hokkaido and another 700 miles before crashing into the Pacific. The launch sent Hokkaido residents scrambling to take shelter, and stirred condemnation among world leaders.Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended 0.5% lower. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index tumbled 0.4%, and currencies went into a frenzy of risk-off trade. Europe's markets traded down sharply in their afternoon session, with Frankfurt's DAX down 1.9%, the CAC-40 in Paris off 1.3% and London's FTSE 100 down 1.1%.Meanwhile, Harvey had moved back out into the U.S. Gulf of Mexico and began to edge north, but continued to dump more than 1 inch per hour of rain Houston on Tuesday, according to the Houston Chronicle, which also reported power outages across the city with no access yet possible for utility repair crews.Oil future traded down 0.3% and gasoline futures jumped 1.4 early Tuesday, as Texas refiners and oil producers remained hunkered down due to weather.  About 2.2 million barrels per day of refining capcity is reported shut down from companies including Exxon Mobil (XOM), Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Valero (VLO) and Phillips 66 (PSX), while Marathon Petroleum (MPC) and LyondellBasell (LYB) reported partial shutdowns.A smaller portion of operations were closed in Texas' Eagle Ford shale production area, with Bentek Energy reporting about 5% of expected output was shut early Tuesday.Airports also remained closed in Houston with the Federal Aviation Administration projecting the closures would last until at least Aug. 30. Bush Intercontinental Airport is the second busiest airport for United Continental Holdings (UAL). Houston's Hobby Airport is an important hub for Southwest Airlines (LUV).Dow stocks traded almost unanimously lower. Nike (NKE) led the downside, dragged down 2.1% by a profit warning from retailer Finish Line (FINL).  Finish Line — a non-Dow stock — collapsed 25% in opening trade, after preliminary results guided Q2 EPS to half the number expected by consensus views, and following a downgrade to neutral, from buy, by FBR Capital. Foot Locker (FL) also felt some of the downdraft, trading 2% lower at the open.Best Buy (BBY) dived 8% at the open, despite scoring a broad second-quarter win. Earnings and revenue growth cleared analyst targets by comfortable margins, and Q3 and full-year earnings and revenue guidance topped consensus views.  The loss sent shares 4% below a 59.79 buy point in a double-bottom base.Watchmaker Movado (MOV) sailed 22% higher at the open, as strong second-quarter results and full-year revenue guidance well above consensus views. THe gain broke shares past two possible buy points — at 25.95 and 26.45 — in an eight week base.Hain Celestrial Group (HAIN) bagged a 3% advannce at the start of trade, following its fiscal Q4 report. The gain provided a nice rebound from support at the stock's 10-week moving average, starting shares up the right side of a month-long consolidation.Gold traded up 1% to above $1,328 an ounce in early action, after surging 1.5% on Monday. Among gold mining stocks, AngloGold Ashanti (AU) jumped 5%. Barrick (ABX) rose 2% and Sibanye Gold (SBGL) gained 3%.The Case-Shiller Housing Price Index grew at a steady, year-over-year rate in June, up 5.7%, lagging just behind expectations for a 5.8% gain.The Conference Board's August consumer confidence index is scheduled for a 10 a.m. ET release.RELATED:The Big Picture: Nasdaq Fights For Support; This Sector RalliesChart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real Opportunity5 Chip Stocks Set Up Bases; Best Buy Due: Investing Action PlanBiogen's Alzheimer's Drug Shows Promise, Stock Nears Buy PointThese 4 Chip Stocks Just Carved This 'Super Growth' PatternETFs: Gold Soars, Biotechs Rally

Stocks opened higher Monday as markets registered only mild initial financial effects of the ongoing flooding that has shut down much of the Texas coast.XThe Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each opened 0.2% higher. The Nasdaq composite also climbed 0.2%.Hurricane Harvey swept in as a category 4 storm late Friday to cause wind damage along the south Texas coast, followed by historical levels of rain-induced flooding of cities north to Houston — the U.S. energy capital and fourth-largest city. The storm was downgraded to tropical storm status, relieving the threat of wind damage, but is projected to continue to deluge the already saturated Houston area with record levels of rainfall.Oil prices dropped almost 1% and gasoline futures surged nearly 4% as refinery operators inspected for possible damage after shutdowns ahead of the storm. About 10 refineries representing an estimated 2.2 million barrels a day of capacity shut down in response to the storm, including flagship facilities owned by Exxon Mobil (XOM) , Valero Energo (VLO)  and Phillips 66 (PSX), according to S&P Platts.All three stocks traded higher at the open. A number of pipelines in the region halted operations, and ports in Corpus Christi and Houston appeared to remain closed to inbound and outbound traffic Monday. About 22% of offshore production in the Gulf of Mexico had reportedly been shut down ahead of the storm.Some insurers trended lower in early action, with Allstate (ALL) down more than 1% and Progressive (PGR) showing a 2% decline.On the Dow, most stocks stuck to gains and losses of less than 0.5%. But Home Depot (HD), a likely beneficiary of demand for building materials in Texas, leapt more than 1% in early action. Building supply peer Lowe's (LOW) rose 1.4%.Servicemaster Global Holdings (SERV), a leader in storm and water damage cleanup and repair, gained 0.5% at the starting bell. Shares of the Memphis, Tenn.-based outfit are extended above a 44.55 buy point in a cup base, and in buy range from a three-weeks tight buy point at 45.41.Apple (AAPL) rose 0.2% and the four FANG stocks were mixed at the start of trade.

With only a small handful of earnings reports due during Monday's session, merger news grabbed early attention. Kite Pharmaceuticals (KITE) soared 29% after the Santa Monica, Calif.-based biotech agreed to an $11.9 billion takeover by Gilead Sciences (GILD). Gilead shares rose more than 2% in opening trade.Other small biotechs received a sympathy boost, with Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) surging 17% and Uniqure (QURE) trading 4% higher. Bluebird Bio (BLUE) jumped 11%.Expedia (EXPE) dropped more than 5%, the heaviest loss among Nasdaq 100 names. Ride services Uber reportedly named Expedia chief executive Dara Kosrowshahi as its CEO on Sunday, as Kosrowshahi beat out contenders Meg Whitman and Jeffrey Immelt for the job. Expedia shares are looking to retake their 10-week moving average as they begin the fifth week of a shallow consolidation.The U.S. traded deficit widened in July to $65.1 billion vs. $63.9 billion in June, the Commerce Department reported — $1 billion wider than the gap projected by economists. Exports decreased 1.3% during the month, imports decreased 0.3%.Wholesale inventories expanded 0.4%, down from June's 0.6% increase. Expansion of retail inventories also slowed for the month.The Dallas Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey is expected at 10:30 a.m. ET.RELATED:These 4 Top Tech Stocks Are A Warning Sign As Nasdaq StrugglesBroadcom Shares Fall Below 50-Day Moving AverageThese 5 Techs Are Near Buy Points In This Classic Bullish PatternChip Stocks & Semiconductor Industry News And AnalysisStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksHow To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple Routine

Berkshire Hathaway's (BRKB) $9 billion cash bid for Energy Future Holdings, and in turn the vast majority of electric transmission utility Oncor, appeared to be in doubt after hedge fund Elliott Management reportedly moved to block the deal.Elliott Management, which has been trying to outbid Berkshire for Oncor, has purchased a type of Energy Future's debt that "closes a potential loophole that Mr. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. could have used to force the deal," the Wall Street Journal said late Wednesday, citing people familiar with the situation.Energy Future Holdings, which filed for bankruptcy protection more than three years ago following a crash in energy prices, is the parent of Oncor. Oncor delivers electricity and other services to nearly 10 million customers in Texas and has held up despite its parent company's difficulties.In a statement late Wednesday, Berkshire Hathaway said it would not raise its offer, in which it would take an 80% stake in Oncor."We appreciate the continued opportunity to collaborate with many stakeholder groups in Texas and thank them for their outstanding support, which sets our offer apart from any other bid," Greg Abel, CEO of Berkshire Hathaway Energy, said then.Berkshire Hathaway announced the deal last month, a move intended to bulk up, or at least reshuffle, the company's holdings in the energy industry. That deal followed an unsuccessful buyout attempt from NextEra (NEE). NextEra's bid fell apart in April.Berkshire also owns a part of Phillips 66 (PSX). The company offloaded its stake in General Electric (GE) in the second quarter.Berkshire rose 0.1% in morning trade in the stock market today.RELATED:Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Dumps General Electric Stake, Trims AirlinesWarren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway In Buy Zone, Gets Rating Upgrade

Has Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) CEO Warren Buffett found another chemical company to acquire?X Lanxess stock shot up in Frankfurt trading after it emerged that Berkshire's General Reinsurance unit is now among the six largest shareholders in the company with a newly disclosed 3% stake in the German company.Buffett may have hinted that he is again on the hunt for an acquisition during a recent trip to another chemical maker, Lubrizol, which Berkshire bought in 2011 for $9.7 billion.During the April 5 visit, he was asked how Lubrizol fit in the Berkshire portfolio. Buffett, who famously invests in old-school industries and companies with a competitive edge, replied that a "terrific business" like Lubrizol takes "decades and decades to build." It was second largest in terms of earnings in his portfolio and a very important asset to Berkshire, he added."Find me another Lubrizol, I'll send flowers your way," he told an interviewer during the visit.Two recent moves by Lanxess CEO Matthias Zachert — a $2.4 billion purchase of Chemtura and a joint rubber-related venture with Saudi Aramco — could make it one of the biggest manufacturers of additives for lubricants and flame retardants, reports said.Lanxess, like Lubrizol, operates chemicals businesses around the world, including the key market of China.Indeed, Buffett's acquisition of Lubrizol was seen as a major bet on emerging markets and overseas growth. The chemical maker's products can be found in everything from heavy-duty industrial engines to personal care products.The Lubrizol purchase came under a cloud when a former director at Berkshire was forced to resign after failing to disclose a prior stake in the company. More recently, Lubrizol incurred a significant loss tied to the purchase of certain oilfield businesses from Weatherford International (WFT).Before Tuesday's news, Lanxess shares had given up 8% since May 11, after its chief executive warned that growth rates are likely to slow in the second half of the year.Berkshire's class B shares were down 0.3% at 165.12 on the stock market today.Buffett has something of a track record of buying equity stakes in a company before purchasing it outright. That happened with the 2010 buyout of railroad company Burlington Northern Santa Fe for $26 billion as well as the 2011 acquisition of Lubrizol.But not all of Berkshire's stakes turn into acquisitions. While Berkshire has loaded up on Phillips 66 (PSX) shares in recent years, ending 2016 with a roughly 16% stake in the oil and gas refiner, there has yet to be a takeover despite some talk of a possibility.RELATED:Is Warren Buffett About To Make His Next Mega Acquisition? 2014: A Look Back And Ahead A buoyant market in 2013 surprised even the most steadfast bulls. From an industry perspective, the year's advance was broad — 186 out of 197 industry groups moved higher. Some 51 groups climbed more than 50%. The top four industries posted triple-digit gains for the year: Auto makers (up 173%), solar energy (168%), consumer…
Stock futures halved their already narrow gains ahead of Wednesday's start of trade.

Dow futures remained 8.9 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were ahead 2.1 points while S&P 500 futures clung to a fractional gain. Small caps were lagging, with Russell 2000 futures trading down 3.4 points.

The stock market today sets out still seeking direction after Tuesday's trade was held to mild losses by broad gains among oil-related stocks. Volume will be crucial, as the Nasdaq and S&P 500 work to shake off some of the eight distribution days each weighed against them. These indicate dominant selling by institutional investors and signal investors to remain on guard until the market's direction becomes clearer.
Economic News
The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil storage data at 10:30 a.m. ET. Minutes from the Federal Reserve's March 18 meeting are due out at 2 p.m.
Stocks

A number of China-based stocks spiked in premarket action, possibly bolstered by the day's rally in Hong Kong. Yanzhou Coal Mining (YZC) swept up 20%. China South Airline (ZNH) and Aluminum Corp. of China (ACH) skipped up 9% each.

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) dropped more than 2% after announcing it would pay more than $70 billion to acquire U.K.-based BG Group. The cash-stock deal is reported to be the largest energy sector transaction in a decade and would create a powerhouse of liquefied natural gas production and infrastructure assets. The offer was reportedly a 52% premium to BG's closing price on Tuesday.

San Diego-based Regulus Therapeutics (RGLS) sped ahead 9% before the open. The company reported AstraZeneca (AZN) had selected Regulus' RG-125 (AZD4076) as the first compound for clinical development under a joint development deal. AstraZeneca will pay Regulus $2.5 million linked to the selection and will handle further development following an investigational new drug application, the companies reported. AstraZeneca shares rose 1%.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose 3% in premarket action. The automaker's blog said the company was set to introduce an all-wheel drive Model S sedan with a 250-mile range. The stock gained 3% last week and 6% this week through Tuesday. That was enough to retake its 10-week moving average. Shares remain 30% below their September high.
Overseas

Stocks in Hong surged, with the Hang Seng index leaping 3.8% — its largest one-day gain in more than three years. Trade was fueled by mainland investors making use of the recently activated Hong Kong/Shanghai trading link, with volume on the link reaching its $1.7 billion limit for the first time since its launch in October. The Shanghai Composite edged up 0.8%.
In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.8%.
Europe's leading indexes were narrowly mixed at midday.
Currencies/Commodities

The dollar gave up ground vs. both the euro and the yen. Oil prices backed off a bit after a two-day rally. U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude dropped more than 2% to below $53 per barrel. Europe's Brent slipped a bit less, holding above $58. Gold, silver and copper were down a fraction. Shares of Delta Air Lines (DAL) surged to a five-year high after the carrier said it expected a second-quarter profit from its refinery.

Speaking at an industry investment conference, Delta President Edward Bastian said operational issues limited its Trainer, Pa., refinery to about 75% capacity over much of the first quarter. But it expects the plant to break even in Q1 and be back up to 100% capacity this week. Without those Q1 "teething pains," the company said the refinery could have made a profit of $60 million in the quarter.
Delta shares were up over 4% intraday on the stock market today.
Delta bought the plant last year from Phillips 66 (PSX), with the hopes of slashing $300 million a year off its jet fuel tab.

At the same JPMorgan Chase investor conference, Southwest Airlines (LUV) said it expects low-single-digit percentage growth in its unit revenue — a key airline metric. It also said March bookings looked solid.
Southwest shares were up 0.8% intraday.

At the conference, JetBlue Airways (JBLU) said it expects to expand partnership arrangement with the new American Airlines after US Airways (LCC) completes its reverse merger. Refineries as a group have been doing well in the past few months as crude remains cheap at home and expensive abroad. But government regulations on fuel blends could weigh heavily on refiners' earnings. Industry giant Valero (VLO) kicks off refinery earnings Tuesday. Analysts expect the company to report a 219% jump in earnings to 99 cents per share. But…
Phillips 66 (PSX) and Marathon Petroleum Corp.'s (MPC) reported fourth-quarter earnings above analyst estimates early Wednesday as the boom in cheap domestic crude oil helped boost production.

Phillips 66 said Q4 EPS was $2.06, beating analyst estimates of $1.68. The company processed 135,000 barrels per day of shale crude during the quarter, a 97% increase from 2011 as big oil changed its focus from natgas "fracking" in Appalachia to the shale oil fields of the Dakotas.
The company's worldwide refining utilization fell to 91% from 94% in 2011 due to the temporary closure of Phillip's Bayway Refinery in New Jersey in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.
Shares hit a new intraday high of 62.91.
Phillips was formed in May from the spinoff of ConocoPhillips' (COP) refining, marketing, chemicals and transportation division.
Marathon Petroleum reported Q4 earnings of $2.24 per share vs. a 21-cent-per-share loss in 2011. Analysts were expecting $2.10. Revenue rose 6.6% to $20.7 billion, above estimates of $19 billion.
Shares hit a new high of 73.40 during midday trading.

Both companies are looking to expand refining operations in the coming year. Phillips 66 expects an 80% jump in domestic crude processed in 2013. Marathon is raising the capacity of its Detroit refinery by 13%.
On Tuesday Valero Energy (VLO) reported fourth-quarter profit and revenue above analyst views as it replaced imported light crude oil with the cheaper domestic oil.

"Since we expect U.S. and Canadian crude oils to become increasingly more available, we are pursuing options to process additional volumes of these cost-advantaged crudes throughout our refining system," CEO Bill Klesse said.
Shares jumped 12% on the news before falling 2.3% on Wednesday.

Not all refiners are trying to expand operations during the oil boom. On Monday, Hess (HESS) said it has plans to sell 20 oil terminals and close its Port Reading, N.J., refinery and will exit the refining business.
Hess shares jumped 16% in the two days following the announcement before falling 2.3% on Wednesday.

The boom in cheap domestic gas is expected to have a mixed effect on big oil. ConocoPhillips is expected to report a 30% drop in fourth-quarter EPS to $1.42 due to the spinoff of Phillips 66 when it reports earnings after the market closes Wednesday. Revenue is seen falling 79% to $13.3 billion.

Refiners shares continued to tumble for the second day as investors and analysts worried about profit margins in the face of potential stricter regulations.

Valero Energy (VLO) shares lost 5% in the stock market today after falling 5.7% on Tuesday. CVR Energy (CVI) fell 4.7% intraday. Phillips 66 (PSX) shares plunged more than 7%. Marathon Petroleum (MPC) shares were down nearly 7%.
Last week, the EPA said a White House proposal to reduce the amount of sulfur in gasoline and raise auto emission standards would raise gasoline prices by less than a penny a gallon.
Refiners would take on the majority of the cost, and, if passed, the new ruling would have serious consequences to their low-margin business.
On Tuesday, Valero told the Wall Street Journal that it expects to spend $300 million to $400 million building new equipment and revamping existing facilities to meet the more rigid standards.
If approved, the EPA won't begin enforcing the new standards until 2017.
After Valero's comments, a Macquarie analyst lowered his Q1 EPS outlook on the company from $1.36 to 99 cents. He lowered Tesoro's (TSO) EPS outlook to 73 cents from $1.01.

Large oil companies have been spinning off their downstream operations to focus on the more lucrative upstream segment. ConocoPhillips (COP) spun off its refining arm, now known as Phillips 66, last May.

But refiners had been outperforming other oil related companies. IBD's Oil & Gas-Refining/Marketing group is ranked No. 14 out of the 197 groups tracked. The Oil & Gas-Integrated group is ranked at No. 179.
International demand from Mexico, Venezuela and Europe rose and prices fell for natural gas at home, helping boost the refining industry the past year.
But refiners hit a rough patch the last month.

On March 13, Macquarie analysts downgraded Valero and HollyFrontier (HFC) to neutral from outperform and CVR Energy to underperform on concerns the companies wouldn't meet federally mandated renewable fuel blends.Refiners shares continued to tumble for the second day as investors and analysts worried about profit margins in the face of potential stricter regulations.Valero Energy (VLO) shares lost 5% in the stock market today after falling 5.7% on Tuesday. Hurricane Sandy's potential economic losses reach $100 billion under the most dire predictions, but even a more moderate impact will be hard to offset for sectors that can't easily ramp up production after the storm passes.
U.S. stock markets will remain closed Tuesday with hopes to reopen Wednesday. The canceled trading days are the first since after the 9/11 attacks.
Most manufacturers have excess capacity, which will allow them to make up for lost output by temporarily running for longer hours or adding more shifts.

But refineries had little spare capacity even before Sandy and are unlikely to fully reverse the shutdown's effects, said Mark Vitner, senior economist at Wells Fargo. Phillips 66 (PSX) and Hess (HES) shut refineries in New Jersey.

Leisure and travel companies will also lose business from conferences that can't be rescheduled, he added. More than 12,000 flights have been canceled, including United Continental (UAL) and US Airways (LCC) flights.
"There are some things you just can't make up," he said, predicting Sandy will cut Q4 GDP by 0.1-0.2 percentage point.
Stores that lose sales during storms could get a bounce when business returns to normal. But refinery outages will lift gas prices and could prevent con sumers from buying other things.
Grocers and home improvement chains like Home Depot (HD) will see more business like they usually do during major storms.
Online sales could get a boost — where the power is on — as storm-area shoppers stay home, though delivery may be affected.

Sandy also will leave businesses wondering how badly they will be hit, how long their customers will stay away and how severely supply chains will be disrupted, said Sal Guatieri, senior economist at BMO Capital Markets.
"This massive storm is just another element of uncertainty that could undermine business confidence," he said.

Rebuilding could leave some areas better off economically, said Peter Morici, an economics professor at the University of Maryland, in a note to subscribers. He predicts Sandy will trigger $15 billion-$20 billion in new private spending that includes more economically productive capital.

"Disasters can give the ailing construction sector a boost and unleash smart reinvestment that actually improves stricken areas and the lives of those that survive intact," he wrote.Hurricane Sandy's potential economic losses reach $100 billion under the most dire predictions, but even a more moderate impact will be hard to offset for sectors that can't easily ramp up production after the storm passes.U.S. stock markets will remain closed Tuesday with hopes to reopen Wednesday. Record high gas prices for the holiday are not expected to deter Americans looking to squeeze in one last summer trip before fall starts.

August gas prices rose from $3.51 a gallon on Aug. 1 to a high of $3.829 a gallon on Aug. 31, the largest August price increase since 2005, according to AAA on Friday. The spike in prices came from the rising costs of crude oil, regional supply problems in the Midwest and closures of Gulf Coast refineries before Hurricane Isaac.
Before the storm, Phillips 66 (PSX) closed its refinery in Belle Chasse, La., and Marathon Petroleum (MPC) reduced production rates at its Garyville, La., refinery.
Phillips 66 shares were up nearly 3% in midday trading, while Marathon was up less than 1%.
Chevron's (CVX) Pascagoula, Miss., refinery remained operational during the storm. Its shares rose 1%.
Several oil companies temporarily shut down offshore rigs in the Gulf due to Isaac, including Exxon Mobil (XOM), BP (BP) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA). All were nearly unchanged in midday trading.
Fallout from the storm and supply problems are expected to continue through the weekend, and AAA sees the national average for gas to be the highest ever.

"People traveling this Labor Day are going to face the most expensive pump prices we have ever seen for this time of year," said AAA spokesperson Avery Ash. "While prices should drop in September barring any major developments, we expect gasoline to remain at or near record highs through the end of 2012."
But despite the increase in prices, Americans are still going to travel for the long weekend, AAA projected.

The company estimated that 33 million Americans will travel 50 miles or more this Labor Day weekend and 28.2 million of those vacationers will be taking their trip by car.Record high gas prices for the holiday are not expected to deter Americans looking to squeeze in one last summer trip before fall starts.August gas prices rose from $3.51 a gallon on Aug. 1 to a high of $3.829 a gallon on Aug. 31, the largest August price increase since 2005, according to AAA on Friday. The spike in prices came from the rising costs of crude oil, regional supply problems in the Midwest and closures of Gulf Coast refineries before Hurricane Isaac.Before the storm, Phillips 66 (PSX) closed its refinery in Belle Chasse, La., and Marathon Petroleum (MPC) reduced production rates at its Garyville, La., refinery.Phillips 66 shares were up nearly 3% in midday trading, while Marathon was up less than 1%.Chevron's (CVX) Pascagoula, Miss., refinery remained operational during the storm. Its shares rose 1%.Several oil companies temporarily shut down offshore rigs in the Gulf due to Isaac, including Exxon Mobil (XOM), BP (BP) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA). All were nearly unchanged in midday trading.Fallout from the storm and supply problems are expected to continue through the weekend, and AAA sees the national average for gas to be the highest ever."People traveling this Labor Day are going to face the most expensive pump prices we have ever seen for this time of year," said AAA spokesperson Avery Ash. "While prices should drop in September barring any major developments, we expect gasoline to remain at or near record highs through the end of 2012."But despite the increase in prices, Americans are still going to travel for the long weekend, AAA projected.The company estimated that 33 million Americans will travel 50 miles or more this Labor Day weekend and 28.2 million of those vacationers will be taking their trip by car.

Businesses on the Gulf of Mexico are preparing for Hurricane Isaac, which the National Hurricane Center said could grow to a Category 2 hurricane with winds up to 110 mph by the time it hits land Wednesday. Entergy (ETR), which distributes power to 2.8 million customers in Louisiana, Mississippi, Texas and other states in the affected region, says it's shut…
Crude oil prices held steady below $113 a barrel despite Isaac being upgraded to a Category 1 hurricane.
Oil is holding the line even though regulators said Gulf of Mexico refiners have cut production by about 78%.
As of Tuesday afternoon, West Texas Intermediate oil was up 0.8% at 96.24 a barrel and benchmark Brent Crude Oil had edged up 0.2% to $112.47 a barrel.
Gulf coast refiners are at heightened risk for damage because they've been operating near full utilization, J.P. Morgan said in a report.
But price gains could be limited because of reports that the International Energy Agency may release oil reserves as early as September to offset lower refinery output.
Among top-rated refiners with operations near the Gulf coast, Phillips 66 (PSX) was up 3% to 42.32 Tuesday afternoon.
Calumet Specialty Products (CLMT), whose facilities include plants in Northwest Louisiana and Texas, rose 1% in midday trading.
Among other Gulf refiners, Marathon Petroleum (MPC) and Swift Energy (SFY) were up less than 1%.

Some refiners highly rated by IBD aren't in immediate danger because their primary facilities are not near the Gulf, including Delek U.S. Holdings (DK) and Holly Frontier (HFC). Delek was up 1.5% intraday and Holly Frontier had risen 1%.

Oil giant Chevron (CVX) has said it would shut some refining facilities, but planned to keep others, including a 330,000-barrel-a-day facility in Pascagoula, Miss. in operation. Chevron shares were up 1% to 112.64 Tuesday afternoon.
Oil transport companies could be affected by diminished supplies.

Among leading companies in the Oil & Transport/Pipeline group, ranked 69 on the list of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD, are Oiltanking Partners (OILT), which climbed 2% intraday, Sunoco Logistics (SXL), which gained 1% and Plains All American (PAA), which traded down a fraction.

Shares of highly-rated oil refining company Tesoro (TSO) jumped nearly 10% Monday morning after it said it will acquire a BP (BP) refinery and related assets in Southern California for about $2.5 billion.

Tesoro, an independent refiner, said it will pay $1.18 billion for BP's refining and marketing business in Carson, Calif. It will also pay BP for the value of the refinery's inventory at the time the deal closes, currently valued at roughly $1.3 billion.

Meanwhile, market research company IIR Energy said Chevron 's (CVX) Richmond, Calif. refinery may be shut down for at least six months for repairs after fire caused extensive damage to the sole crude oil refining unit at the site.

In a report Friday, IIR Energy said investigators have found serious damage in the cooling towers, pipe racks and heater tower. Chevron hadn't yet provided a timetable for repairs at the facility, which processed 245,000 barrels per day. Gas prices have spiked in the wake of the refinery fire, topping $4 a gallon in California and major cities, like Chicago.

Tesoro said after the acquisition of BP's refinery is complete, it plans to combine operations of its 103,800-barrel-per-day Wilmington, Calif. refinery with those of the Carson refinery, which refines 266,000 bpd by 2015.

Tesoro shares were up 8.5% to 38.85 in midday trading. The company's shares have risen about 35% since it reported on Aug. 2 that second-quarter profit jumped 74% to $2.87, as revenue edged up 2% to $8.105 billion, both above analyst estimates.
Elsewhere in the Oil & Gas-Refining/Marketing group, ranked a lofty No. 10 of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks, InterOil (IOC), which reports results after the market closes, fell 4% to 87.36.
Valero (VLO) slid 1.2% to 28.57, Philips 66 (PSX) was up a fraction to 40.11 and Western Refining (WNR) rose 0.8% to 26.33.
BP shares slipped 0.5% to 42.17.
Among other companies in the Oil & Gas-Integrated group, which has dropped to a 128 rank, Exxon Mobil (XOM) was trading down slightly, and Chevron dropped 0.6% to 112.92.
